<div class="responsivegrid cmp-di-layout-container--content-section aem-GridColumn aem-GridColumn--default--12">


<div class="aem-Grid aem-Grid--12 aem-Grid--default--12 ">
    
    <div class="text cmp-standard-rte--60-width aem-GridColumn aem-GridColumn--default--12">
<div class="cmp-text">
    <h3><a id="understanding"></a>Understanding what drives student success</h3>
<p>Success in higher education is a combination of affordable access, persistence, completion, and transition to the workforce. Moreover, for many low-income learners, a college degree can serve as their ticket out of poverty. Today, many colleges and universities across the United States are falling short at each of these milestones.<br>
</p>

</div>

    

</div>
<div class="pagenavigation cmp-nav--title-image cmp-nav--title-image--40-width cmp--float-right cmp--width-40 aem-GridColumn aem-GridColumn--default--12">


  
  <div class="cmp-nav">
    <div class="cmp-nav__container">
      
        <strong class="cmp-nav__title">Learn more</strong>
      
      <ul class="cmp-nav__list">
        
        
          <li class="cmp-nav__item">
            <a href="/us/en/insights/industry/public-sector.html?icid=learn_more_content_click" target="_self" class="cmp-nav__link">Explore the Government & public services collection
              
            </a>
            
          </li>
        
          <li class="cmp-nav__item">
            <a href="#deloitte-services" target="_self" class="cmp-nav__link">Learn about Deloitte's services
              
            </a>
            
          </li>
        
          <li class="cmp-nav__item">
            <a href="/us/en/insights/legal/deloitte-insights-app.html?icid=learn_more_content_click" target="_self" class="cmp-nav__link">Go straight to smart. Get the Deloitte Insights app
              
            </a>
            
          </li>
        
        
      </ul>
      <span hidden="" id="pagenavigation_newWindowAlert">
        
      </span>
    </div>
  </div>
  
</div>
<div class="text cmp-standard-rte--60-width aem-GridColumn aem-GridColumn--default--12">
<div class="cmp-text">
    <p>The challenges are especially acute for low-income and first-generation learners.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-1" href="#endnote-1">1</a></sup> Dependent students who are both low-income and first-generation college learners have a 21% chance of completing a bachelorâ€™s degree in six years, compared to a 66% chance among other students.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-2" href="#endnote-2">2</a></sup></p>
<p>The same disparity can be seen in enrollment rates. In 2020, 29% of households with at least one student expected to start college canceled their studentsâ€™ fall enrollmentâ€”with Black, Hispanic, low- and middle-income, and first-generation households being the most likely to do so.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-3" href="#endnote-3">3</a></sup></p>
<p>Despite the dismal data, many colleges and universities <i>are</i> delivering strong outcomes for those most at risk and have continued to achieve strong results during the tumultuous past year.</p>
<p>To help students complete their education and thrive, institutions need to invest wisely in strategies that will deliver the best outcomes. While student success is a complex endeavor and no two institutions follow the exact same path, this report, through a series of interviews with senior leaders at seven leading colleges and universities, identifies five impactful strategies these institutions are deploying to help students succeed in their collegiate endeavors and beyondâ€”from increased access and affordability through certificate/degree completion, to strong labor market outcomes and improved social mobility rates (see sidebar, â€œMethodologyâ€). Those strategies include:</p>
<ul><li>Helping students develop resiliency</li><li>Harnessing innovation to improve mental health</li><li>Using analytics to identify obstacles to graduation</li><li>Prioritizing inclusion for first-generation students</li><li>Removing friction from the transfer process</li></ul>

</div>

    

</div>
<div class="aside aem-GridColumn aem-GridColumn--default--12"><div class="cmp-aside">
    <div class="cmp-aside__content" style="max-height: 330px; overflow: hidden;">
	    <h3 class="cmp-aside__content__title">Methodology</h3>
    	<div class="cmp-aside__content__desc">
 			


<div class="aem-Grid aem-Grid--12 aem-Grid--default--12 ">
    
    <div class="text aem-GridColumn aem-GridColumn--default--12">
<div class="cmp-text">
    <p>Drawing on data from multiple sourcesâ€”<a href="https://nces.ed.gov/ipeds/">Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System</a>, <a href="https://collegescorecard.ed.gov/">College Scorecard</a>, <a href="https://opportunityinsights.org/paper/undermatching/">Raj Chetty et alâ€™s Income segregation and intergenerational mobility across colleges in the United States dataset</a>, and <a href="https://cew.georgetown.edu/cew-reports/CollegeROI/">Georgetown University Center on Education and the Workforceâ€™s College ROI dataset</a>â€”we analyzed more than 1,500 four-year colleges and universities in the United States to understand which institutions do the best job of serving students across the student life cycle, from access and affordability through certificate/degree completion, to labor market outcomes and improved social mobility. For more detail, please refer to â€œ<a href="https://www2.deloitte.com/us/en/insights/industry/public-sector/interactive-benchmarking-in-higher-education.html?id=us:2em:3na:4diUS164697:5awa::012422::author&pkid=1008138%20">Student success benchmarking in higher education.</a>â€ Leading institutions are defined as those that outperform their Carnegie peers or other four-year institutions across multiple parameters, including:</p>
<ul><li>Access: enrollment of underrepresented minorities (URMs), Pell Grant recipients, and first-generation students</li><li>Affordability: in-state average tuition for full-time students and in-state per-credit-hour charge for part-time undergraduates</li><li>Completion: six-year graduation rates for URMs and Pell Grant recipients, and eight-year completion rates for nonâ€“first-time, part-time students</li><li>Labor market outcomes: median earnings 10 years after entry, 10-year net present value (NPV) score,<sup><a id="endnote-sup-4" href="#endnote-4">4</a></sup> and three-year cohort default rate</li><li>Social mobility rate: joint probability of parents in the bottom quintile and child in the top quintile of the income distribution</li></ul>

</div>

    

</div>

    
</div>

		</div>
    </div>
	<div id="true" class="cmp-aside__control-container">
        <div class="cmp-aside__control cmp-aside__control__collapse in-active">
            <button class="cmp-aside__control__btn">Show less</button>
            <span class="cmp-aside-icon"><i class="icon-decrease"></i></span>
        </div>
        <div class="cmp-aside__control cmp-aside__control__expand active" aria-expanded="true">
            <button class="cmp-aside__control__btn">Show more</button>
            <span class="cmp-aside-icon"><i class="icon-increase"></i></span>
        </div>
    </div>
</div></div>
<div class="text aem-GridColumn aem-GridColumn--default--12">
<div class="cmp-text">
    <h3><a id="one"></a>Strategy no. 1: Help students develop resiliency</h3>
<p style="	margin-left: 40.0px;
"><i>â€œFailure is not fatal and itâ€™s never final.â€</i></p>
<p style="	margin-left: 40.0px;
">â€”<i>Lawrence Ward, vice president and dean of campus life, Babson College</i><br>
</p>
<p>Leading institutions that we interviewed made a point of intentionally developing resiliencyâ€”learning not to be discouraged by past failings and having the capacity to spring back from both the small, everyday stressors and challenges of life as well as the major hurdlesâ€”as part of their first-year experience. This type of resiliency helps students persist not only academically, but also in their post-collegiate endeavors.<br>
</p>
<p><i></i>At Babson College, for instance, students learn to â€œfail again, fail forward.â€ As part of its Foundations of Management and Entrepreneurship program, first-year student teams create a business. They then take the business through its entire life cycleâ€”from initial concept to bringing the concept to market, to selling a product or service, and, finally, to shutting the business down.</p>
<p>â€œWhat students donâ€™t understand is that itâ€™s intentionally designed to be a lesson in failure,â€ explains Lawrence Ward, vice president and dean of campus life at Babson College. â€œStudents learn that they have no idea what they're doing in their first year. Then the second, third, and fourth years are about building students up and giving them a foundation, not only in business, but in principles of innovation.â€<sup><a id="endnote-sup-5" href="#endnote-5">5</a></sup><br>
</p>
<p>This process of learning to fail and then using that as a foundation for future innovation can help students cultivate professional resiliency, especially in the long term (figure 1). â€œFewer than 10% of our students actually graduate and start their own business,â€ says Ward, â€œbut that the number jumps to 40%, 10 years after graduation.â€<sup><a id="endnote-sup-6" href="#endnote-6">6</a></sup></p>

</div>

    

</div>

<div class="text aem-GridColumn aem-GridColumn--default--12">
<div class="cmp-text">
    <h3><a id="two"></a>Strategy no. 2: Harness innovation to improve mental health</h3>
<p style="	margin-left: 40.0px;
"><i>â€œItâ€™s about connecting students as quickly as possible to people who can help.â€</i></p>
<p style="	margin-left: 40.0px;
">â€”<i>Darcy Van Patten, chief technology officer, University of Arizona (UArizona) </i><br>
</p>
<p>Mental health and well-being have become increasingly important to higher education leaders across the country. According to the most recent American Council on Education Pulse Survey, nearly three-fourths of over 240 presidents surveyed rated mental health as the most pressing issue.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-7" href="#endnote-7">7</a></sup> â€œLike many other institutions, weâ€™ve observed a real increase in the number of students reporting isolation, depression, anxiety,â€ observes David Burge, vice president of enrollment management, George Mason University (GMU). â€œIt puts a lot more demand on counseling and psychological services and coaching.â€<sup><a id="endnote-sup-8" href="#endnote-8">8</a></sup></p>
<p>One reason for growing anxiety and depression among college students is the pressure to succeed. Financial pressure, especially among minority and low-income students, is another.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-9" href="#endnote-9">9 </a></sup>COVID-19 has only accelerated this trend. In one study of 33,000 students in the fall of 2020, half of the students indicated that they experienced depression or anxiety;<sup><a id="endnote-sup-10" href="#endnote-10">10</a></sup> in another study by the Healthy Minds Network, 60% of students said the pandemic made it harder to access mental health care.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-11" href="#endnote-11">11</a></sup> Moreover, research from Salesforce.org shows that 76% of students say they have trouble <a href="https://www.salesforce.org/blog/wellbeing-higher-education/">maintaining their well-being</a>, as do 73% of staff.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-12" href="#endnote-12">12</a></sup><br>
</p>
<p>The need for even more counseling services has put additional pressure on financially strained colleges. However, itâ€™s also spurred institutions to think creatively about how to meet the increased demand, including through technology tools. A case in point is UArizona. Because the university had previously recognized and heard from students that mental health was a huge need, it had already invested some strategic initiative funding in improving staffing and providing more counseling support for students. So, when the pandemic hit, the institution was quickly able to implement telehealth technology for remote counseling services.<br>
</p>
<p><b>â€œ</b>Technology can help students self-assess and reflect on their needs. When theyâ€™re ready to reach out for support, we can connect them as quickly as possible to people who can help,â€ says Darcy Van Patten, CTO at UArizona.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-13" href="#endnote-13">13</a></sup><br>
</p>

</div>

    

</div>
<div class="aside aem-GridColumn aem-GridColumn--default--12"><div class="cmp-aside">
    <div class="cmp-aside__content" style="max-height: 330px; overflow: hidden;">
	    <h3 class="cmp-aside__content__title">Specialized programs give students more options for mental health well-being</h3>
    	<div class="cmp-aside__content__desc">
 			


<div class="aem-Grid aem-Grid--12 aem-Grid--default--12 ">
    
    <div class="text aem-GridColumn aem-GridColumn--default--12">
<div class="cmp-text">
    <p>Growing counseling wait lists are pushing universities to pursue new approaches to delivering mental health services. A recent report on student well-being found that 34% of campus counseling centers have wait lists with an average of 51 students waiting for counseling appointments.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-14" href="#endnote-14">14</a></sup><br>
</p>
<p>Apart from using technology to scale support, some colleges are also implementing specialized programs that can augment professional counseling services. For example, UArizona is implementing apps and peer-to-peer networks, where students certified in psychological first aid can offer virtual support groups for other students.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-15" href="#endnote-15">15</a></sup></p>

</div>

    

</div>

    
</div>

		</div>
    </div>
	<div id="true" class="cmp-aside__control-container">
        <div class="cmp-aside__control cmp-aside__control__collapse in-active">
            <button class="cmp-aside__control__btn">Show less</button>
            <span class="cmp-aside-icon"><i class="icon-decrease"></i></span>
        </div>
        <div class="cmp-aside__control cmp-aside__control__expand active" aria-expanded="true">
            <button class="cmp-aside__control__btn">Show more</button>
            <span class="cmp-aside-icon"><i class="icon-increase"></i></span>
        </div>
    </div>
</div></div>
<div class="text aem-GridColumn aem-GridColumn--default--12">
<div class="cmp-text">
    <h3><a id="three"></a>Strategy no. 3: Use analytics to identify obstacles to graduation</h3>
<p style="	margin-left: 40.0px;
"><i>â€œYou would never think a C in psychology was going to be a gatekeeper.â€</i></p>
<p style="	margin-left: 40.0px;
"><i>â€”Anthony Allen, former senior vice president at Monroe College</i></p>
<p>Many institutions have invested in developing their analytical capabilities as part of their student success strategy. Far fewer have put this data to meaningful use. However, if used properly, data can offer valuable insights to support student success.<br>
</p>
<p>Monroe College is a good example of applying data to improve student outcomes (figure 2). Monroe serves an undergraduate student body of 5,500 and boasts a full-time retention rate of 82% (compared to the average of 63% for all private for-profit colleges).<sup><a id="endnote-sup-16" href="#endnote-16">16</a></sup> Data analytics has yielded surprising new insights at Monroe by providing a more macro view of performance data. For example, data has shown that a less alarming indicator such as a student getting a C in psychology can be the red flag that they're not going to make it, according to Anthony Allen, former senior vice president at Monroe College: â€œYou would never think a C in psychology was going to be a gatekeeper.â€<sup><a id="endnote-sup-17" href="#endnote-17">17</a></sup><br>
</p>
<p>With the pivot to remote learning during the pandemic, many institutions were forced to use the full functionality of their learning management systems (LMSs), which have proven to be a valuable source of data for understanding engagement and other student success metrics. The University of Central Florida (UCF), which enrolls over 58,000 undergraduates, uses real-time data insights from its LMS on studentsâ€™ performance in specific courses to scale intervention efforts.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-18" href="#endnote-18">18</a></sup><br>
</p>
<p>According to Thomas Cavanagh, vice provost of digital learning at UCF, what the university discovered was that neither logins nor frequent engagement in a course were predictive of success; however, how students did on assigned graded activities was highly predictive. â€œIf we add course activity to the GPA data, we can get up to 90% accurate prediction of a student's likelihood for success,â€ says Cavanagh. â€œWhat we're trying to do now is translate that into some actionable tactics,â€ for instance, by displaying the data in a way that leads to actual interventions.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-19" href="#endnote-19">19</a></sup><br>
</p>

</div>

    

</div>

<div class="text aem-GridColumn aem-GridColumn--default--12">
<div class="cmp-text">
    <h3><a id="four"></a>Strategy no. 4: Prioritize inclusion for first-generation students </h3>
<p style="	margin-left: 40.0px;
"><i>â€œWe want students to understand that their feelings are normal and that they've earned their spot here.â€</i></p>
<p style="	margin-left: 40.0px;
"><i>â€”Monroe Gorden, vice chancellor of student affairs, University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA)</i><br>
</p>
<p>First-generation students currently make up a third (32%) of the student body at selective institutions, and just under a quarter (22%) at more selective institutions.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-20" href="#endnote-20">20</a></sup> But they face formidable challenges in staying enrolled. One-third of first-generation students drop out of college after three years, compared to just 14% of students whose parents earned a degree.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-21" href="#endnote-21">21</a></sup></p>
<p>One reason first-generation students struggle is that they are often low-income and minority students and are more apt to feel out of place.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-22" href="#endnote-22">22</a></sup> However, institutions that have found ways to help their first-generation students feel they belong there have a higher graduation rate.<br>
</p>
<p>UCLA, for example, has an 80% completion rate for first-generation students, which is higher than the average for its Carnegie peers and other four-year public institutions (figure 3). Programs such as its Academic Advancement Program (AAP) provide an increasingly diverse population across the state better access to academic, personal, and professional development through academic advising, peer learning, and collaborative learning workshops. Underlying the program is the belief that all AAP students have earned their place at UCLA through their academic track record. About 80% of AAP students are the first in their family to pursue higher education.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-23" href="#endnote-23">23</a></sup><br>
</p>
<p>â€œThe program creates an environment for underrepresented students where they feel part of the fabric of UCLA,â€ notes Monroe Gorden, vice chancellor of student affairs at UCLA.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-24" href="#endnote-24">24<br>
</a></sup></p>
<p>UCLAâ€™s First Year Experience office also offers several programs that provide URM students access to counseling and psychological services as well as resiliency programs.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-25" href="#endnote-25">25</a></sup><br>
</p>

</div>

    

</div>

<div class="text aem-GridColumn aem-GridColumn--default--12">
<div class="cmp-text">
    <h4><a id="what"></a>What it takes to close the first-generation graduation gap</h4>
<p style="	margin-left: 40.0px;
">â€œ<i>We're making significant progress. We think the gap could be eliminated by the time we reach 2025.â€</i></p>
<p style="	margin-left: 40.0px;
"><i>â€”Berhanu Tadesse, associate vice president for IT and academic technology services, California State University, Fullerton (CSUF)</i><sup><a id="endnote-sup-26" href="#endnote-26">26</a></sup></p>
<p>At CSUF, designated as a Hispanic-serving institution and an Asian American and Native American Pacific Islander-serving institution, one of the objectives as part of its Graduation Initiative 2025 has been to increase the graduation rate for underrepresented students. The initiative lays out an ambitious plan to increase the first-time freshmen four-year graduation rate from 22% to 44% and transfer studentsâ€™ two-year graduation rate from 32% to 44%.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-27" href="#endnote-27">27</a></sup></p>
<p>CSUF has seen strong results from its First Year Experience program, which is designed to improve retention and graduation rates by quickly building studentsâ€™ sense of belonging, proficiency, and confidence through summer bridge programs, student mentorships, and orientation programs.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-28" href="#endnote-28">28</a></sup> CSUF has also increased its investment in advising through cross-divisional collaboration between Academic Affairs and Student Affairs that has expanded â€œdrive-throughâ€ advisement opportunities to counsel students on their transcripts and graduation requirements. In addition, all students with 75â€“89 units have holds placed on their registration until they attend a mandatory advising workshop.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-29" href="#endnote-29">29</a></sup><br>
</p>
<p>Finally, CSUF has deployed a Student Success Dashboard that pulls data from multiple sources into a single, cohesive, interactive tool. This dashboard is widely used by graduation and retention specialists to target students for active interventions and advising, with the goal of preventing attrition and graduation deferrals.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-30" href="#endnote-30">30</a></sup><br>
</p>
<p>Figure 4 shows the impact of CSUFâ€™s efforts.<br>
</p>

</div>

    

</div>

<div class="text aem-GridColumn aem-GridColumn--default--12">
<div class="cmp-text">
    <h3><a id="five"></a>Strategy no. 5: Remove friction from the transfer process</h3>
<p style="	margin-left: 40.0px;
"><i>â€œThe [ADVANCE] program is set up, so students have an existence at both institutions. Students have the same coach at both places to help them migrate through the system once they reach approximately 60 credit hours.â€ </i></p>
<p style="	margin-left: 40.0px;
"><i>â€”David Burge, vice president for enrollment management, GMU</i></p>
<p>With 40% of undergraduate students enrolled at community colleges and a significant percentage of those seeking to eventually obtain a bachelorâ€™s degree, two-year institutions are an important focus area to increase bachelorâ€™s degree attainment.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-31" href="#endnote-31">31</a></sup> Yet, the numbers are not promising: Not only will fewer than a third of community college students end up transferring to four-year institutions, but an even smaller percentage (14%) are successful in attaining a bachelorâ€™s degree within six years of entry.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-32" href="#endnote-32">32</a></sup><br>
</p>
<p>To make the path from community college to a four-year degree more attainable, 19 states currently offer tuition-free community college to eligible residents.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-32" href="#endnote-33">33</a></sup> Meanwhile, US President Joe Biden is seeking funding of US $109 billion for these two-year colleges, along with US $39 billion for two yearsâ€™ worth of free tuition at minority-serving institutions for most students.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-34" href="#endnote-34">34</a></sup><br>
</p>
<p>However, funding isnâ€™t the only issue. Lack of information and transfer shockâ€”a phenomenon in which transfer students are left confused by the new landscapeâ€”also create friction during the transfer from community college to a four-year institution.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-35" href="#endnote-35">35</a></sup> In response, some four-year colleges have begun partnering with two-year feeder schools to create guided and holistic pathways for transfer students. <br>
</p>
<p>For its part, GMU launched ADVANCE, a pathway-based program for students at Northern Virginia Community College (NOVA). The program makes transferring from NOVA to GMU effortless by eliminating the application process.<sup><a id="endnote-sup-36" href="#endnote-36">36</a></sup> Once students reach a specific credit milestone, they are migrated over to degree-seeking status at GMU with an automatic transfer of their NOVA credits.<br>
</p>
<p>â€œThe program is set up, so students have an existence at both institutions,â€ explains David Burge, vice president for enrollment management at GMU. â€œStudents have the same coach at both places to help them migrate through the system once they reach approximately 60 credit hours.â€ <br>
</p>
<p>GMU has had a long tradition of serving transfer students before the launch of the ADVANCE program. Almost 50% the undergraduate degrees awarded each year go to former transfer students. Figure 5 shows the impact of these efforts.<br>
</p>

</div>

    

</div>

<div class="text aem-GridColumn aem-GridColumn--default--12">
<div class="cmp-text">
    <h3><a id="looking"></a>Looking ahead</h3>
<p>There is no doubt that the last year has made it even more challenging for students to complete their four-year degrees. But itâ€™s also true that this past year has allowed many institutions to look for more creative and innovative solutions that can help students remain successfully enrolled. </p>
<p>The most successful institutions are those that provide students with added support and mentorship, help reduce friction or roadblocks (whether financial or administrative), and those that use data and analytics to pinpoint where those types of support services will be most valuable.</p>

</div>

    

</div>

<div class="cmp-text">
    <p>The authors are grateful to those who shared their time and insights to make this report possible, including <b>David Noone</b>, <b>Alok Ranjan</b>, <b>Utkarsh Londhe</b>, <b>Kannan Thirumalai</b>, <b>Glynis Rodrigues</b>, and <b>Aishwarya Rai</b> at Deloitte, and <b>Kai Lou</b>, director of strategic partnerships at Salesforce.org, for kicking off this project with Deloitte.</p>
<p>The authors are indebted to the following senior leadership teams that graciously shared their time, insights, and experiences with us: <b>Lawrence Ward</b>, VP and dean of campus life at Babson College; <b>Berhanu Tadesse</b>, AVP for IT and Academic Technology Services at CSUF; <b>Kevin Borek</b>, VP of IT & CIO; and <b>David Burge</b>, VP, Enrollment Management at GMU; <b>Anthony Allen</b>, former SVP, Karenann Carty, SVP, Academic & Student Affairs, and <b>Janice Girardi</b>, AVP, Institutional Assessment at Monroe College; <b>Darcy Van Patten</b>, CTO and <b>Sarah Wieland</b>, assistant vice provost, Distance Education at UArizona;<b> Monroe Gorden</b>, vice-chancellor, Student Affairs and <b>Arun Pasricha</b>, CIO, Student Affairs at UCLA; <b>Theodorea Berry</b>, vice provost, Student Learning & Academic Success, dean of undergraduate studies and <b>Thomas Cavanagh</b>, vice provost, Digital Learning at University of Central Florida; <b>Tammy Aagard</b>, AVP, Enrollment Management, <b>Mary Kay Carodine</b>, AVP, Student Affairs, <b>Brian Karcinski</b>, director, Finance and Admissions, <b>Tobin Shorey</b>, director, Curriculum Monitoring and Analysis, and <b>TJ Summerford</b>, Information Technology principal, Institute of Online Learning at University of Florida.<br>
</p>

	   <p>The path forward is rarely well-paved. Time-tested practices may guide the journey, but they can only map the ground they have covered. Moving forward requires fresh thinking, the courage to venture beyond, and a capable partner to guide you on the way.</p>
<p>As a leading provider of <a href="https://www2.deloitte.com/us/en/pages/public-sector/solutions/higher-education-services.html">higher education professional services</a>, we offer the fresh perspective and unique skills needed to address complex challenges and explore promising opportunities. We bring big ideas and practical solutions to advance teaching, learning, research, and community service. On every step of your transformation journey, weâ€™re here to serve as collaborative partners on your path forward.</p>
<p> </p>
<h4>Salesforce.org</h4>
<p>Salesforce.org is a social impact center of Salesforce. We build powerful technology for, and with, our community of education institutions to help them operate effectively, raise funds, and deepen constituent relationships. In a world where digital-first is no longer a choice, <a href="https://www.salesforce.org/highered/">Education Cloud</a> enables institutions to increase digital engagement, create a single source of truth, and generate actionable insights across the student journey.</p>

    function getCookie(name) 
    {
        var dc = document.cookie;
        var prefix = name + "=";
        var begin = dc.indexOf("; " + prefix);
        if (begin == -1) {
            begin = dc.indexOf(prefix);
            if (begin != 0) return null;
        }
        else
        {
            begin += 2;
            var end = document.cookie.indexOf(";", begin);
            if (end == -1) {
                end = dc.length;
            }
        }
        return unescape(dc.substring(begin + prefix.length, end));
    }
